Patch Set 1:

This is a replacement for a previous attempt here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/40102.
In comparison with that commit: this one is based on external commits which move to libpam_1.5.1 which is required for this function, and this one adds a new convert-pam-config service.

This is co-requisite with https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/39853

Patch Set 2:

The CI failure happens because this change is co-req with https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/39853 bu that change is not on the system.

The CI failure privately reported to me is:
{date} {system} phosphor-user-manager[703]: Group not found
{date} {system} phosphor-user-manager[703]: terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::process::process_error'
{date} {system} phosphor-user-manager[703]:   what():  execve failed: No such file or directory
{date} {system} witherspoon-X systemd[1]: Started Process Core Dump (PID 705/UID 0).

Running the image in QEMU gives a similar result:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::process::process_error'
  what():  execve failed: No such file or directory
Aborted (core dumped)

Running journalctl did not show any "Group not found" messages, so I was not able to replicate that piece.

The image is running the old phosphor-user-manager which uses the tally2 command at startup time to get data for all users.  Running `strings /usr/bin/phosphor-user-manager | grep tally` confirms this:
pam_tally2.so
/usr/sbin/pam_tally2
and does not show any faillock command strings.

Is there a way to remove the co-req change?  Observe that the changes that need to be made to PAM config files (libpam recipe) and phosphor-user-manager are tied together.  For user management (authentication and admin functions) to function, they really do need to be changed at the same time.

Is there a way to remove the co-req from the build process?  I don't see a way.  The obvious sequence is:
 1. Merge a change that enables with the old & new PAM modules.  Specifically, to make libpam_1.3.1 also build the faillock and pwquality modules.
 2. Then merge the phosphor-user-manager commit.
 3. Then merge this commit (after rebase).

In this way, phosphor-user-manager would start up okay.  However, functions would break after the phosphor-user-manager commit merged because its functions (to use the new faillock command) wouldn't match the PAM config files provided by this commit.

Alternately, we could enhance phosphor-user-manager to adapt to conditions (old vs new  pam config), but that seems excessive (and error prone) for a throwaway change.

Patch Set 2:

We built this into an image together with https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/39853 and it passed testing from our test team.

I sent an email about this change.  Example archive: https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/e4dc8f12-4807-cf03-0eea-f19d67387879@linux.ibm.com/T/#u

Done
Was this issue sent upstream? We tend to try and treat the meta-openembedded layer as read-only from an OpenBMC perspective. Could we do a un-inherit in the bbappend?

This is not yet sent upstream because it is not yet in a form they can take.  This recipe PACKAGECONFIG needs to be enhanced.  See discussion in https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/issues/3750

Also, we cannot fix this in a bbappend because the inherit statement are processed before the appends take effect.   don't know how to make bbappend uninherit.

Please note that I have no skills or expertise with bitbake PACKAGECONFIG and would appreciate some help here.  Otherwise, I'll continue to work on this as time allows.
Done
Extra line feed added here
Yep, it is extra.
Ack
Why /lib vs. /usr/lib?

Because Linux-PAM is configured on OpenBMC to searches for modules only in /lib/security and does not search /usr/lib/security.
This is needed to make pam_pwquality.so install where we need it.
Done

Will it be ok to make the conversion service to be part of phosphor-user-manager?
Reason: 
1. This service is required only for FW update scenario in old platforms. For any new platform project / generation this service is totally not required. Hence exposing it in Phosphor-user-manager with a flag to enable / disable will make life easier. So people can use directly new stuff for their new platforms
2. Till this service is finished, phosphor-user-manager must not be started to do the initial query. If phosphor-user-manager races against this service, then initial values may be inconsistent. Hence there must be a dependency. If this .sh can be directly started in phosphor-user-manager, then dependency can be solved.

For 1: Exactly correct.  Good idea.
For 2: Good catch.  I had not thought of that.  Yes, the dependency should be added.
I didn't add a dependency, but I didn't see an issue in my testing.  Since it's a corner case that can be solved with a reboot, I'd prefer to keep the service as simple as possible.

better remove Redfish from here and call the specific property.

Reason: Redfish is one interface which can consume this. We can even use it from IPMI (today in GetLAN / Set LAN bad password threshold is not yet done) or we can expose it through any other interface.
Agreed.  I think we can remove the word "Redfish" from this sentence, and add another example showing the IPMI usage.
Done
In case of downgrade, Factory defaults is recommended to make sure things are working fine, and current logic, won't be able to take care of this settings during downgrade.

Finally, an interested engineer!  :-)
Yes, your wording is better.  Let's change the commit message.
Done
separate this fix. This is not tied to this issue.
Okay.  I think this needs to be a prerequisite change.  I was not able to make the BMC work without this.  And I do not understand how the BMC's are getting through our CI testing.
Done
I have rebased and updated this change to the latest and pulled in libpam 1.5.2 from Yocto.  It is installed and working on my system, so it's ready to go for review again.
Adding Josh who created the original bbappend file for disabling cracklib

Password policy works for me.
However, Redfish's redfish/v1/AccountService does not have AccountLockoutDuration and AccountLockoutThreshold correctly set. I checked /etc/security/faillock.conf has correct values. Wonder if need to update bmcweb for the new change?

There is a corresponding change in phosphor-user-manager to correctly show the AccountLockoutDuration and AccountLockoutThreshold values in Redfish: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/62032.
Looks good to me.

I think this should be: auth required pam_faillock.so authsucc
and then the next line (auth requisite pam_deny.so) is not needed.

Okay.  Can we propose that change as a separate patch?  This is in line with what we currently have in meta-phosphor.  Otherwise, if this is the preferred approach, I will make the change and test it.
Yes.  I +1 approved even without this suggested change.

We're going to need to rebase / refresh this again.  I know the subtree update I just picked up in master has at least one new patch file.  Will be great to see us back aligned with upstream master though!
Done
Looks good to me.
